revisions.rev:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''South Park'' characters}} [[File:SouthParkHD.png|350px|right|thumb|''South Park'' title image with the four main characters ([[Eric Cartman]], [[Stan Marsh]], [[Kyle Broflovski]], and [[Kenny McCormick]]) in the foreground and most of the recurring, supporting characters in the background|alt=four of the main five boys are in the foreground, waving at the viewer. Kenny is climbed on a wooden sign labeled "SOUTH PARK". In the background, the entire population of the city and all the other characters present on the show have gathered, looking at the viewer also.]]
''[[South Park]]'' is an [[Television in the United States|American]] animated [[Situation comedy|sitcom]] created by [[Trey Parker]] and [[Matt Stone]] for the [[Comedy Central]] [[cable television|television network]]. Intended for mature audiences, the show has become infamous for its crude, [[surrealism|surreal]], [[satire|satirical]], and [[Black comedy|dark humor]] that lampoons [[Subject matter in South Park|a wide range of topics]].<ref name="fortune">{{cite news| author = Devin Leonard| title ='South Park' creators haven't lost their edge| publisher = [[CNN]]| date = 2006-10-27|url = http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/fortune_archive/2006/10/30/8391792/index.htm| accessdate = 2009-05-03}}</ref><ref name="crude">{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/crude-violent--but-quite-brilliant-1045072.html|title=Crude, violent - but quite brilliant- Arts & Entertainment|date=1999-01-05|publisher=''[[The Independent]]''|accessdate=2009-05-27|last=Blacker|first=Terence}}</ref> The ongoing narrative revolves around five children, [[Stan Marsh]], [[Kyle Broflovski]], [[Eric Cartman]], [[Kenny McCormick]], and eventually [[Butters Stotch]] and their bizarre adventures in and around the fictional and eponymous [[Colorado]] town.<ref name="statesman">{{cite news | author = Eric Griffiths | title = Young offenders | work = [[New Statesman]] | date = 2007-06-21 | url = http://www.newstatesman.com/books/2007/06/south-park-sex-studies | accessdate = 2009-05-03}}</ref> The town, sometimes described within the show as "a pissant white-bread mountain town",<ref name="nytimesmorals">{{cite news | author = Virginia Heffernan| title = What? Morals in 'South Park'? | work = [[The New York Times]] | date = 2004-04-28| url = http://www.nytimes.com/2004/04/28/arts/television/28SOUT.html?ei=5007&en=9cf4a2bb20610253&ex=1398484800&partner=USERLAND&pagewanted=all&position | accessdate = 2008-07-08}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> is also home to assortment of characters who make frequent appearances in the show such as [[List of students at South Park Elementary|students]] and their [[List of South Park families|family members]], [[List of staff at South Park Elementary|elementary school staff]], and other various [[List of other South Park residents|various residents]], of which only the [[recurring character]]s are listed.<ref name="statesman"/><ref name="nytimesmorals"/>
Stan is portrayed as the [[everyman]] of the group,<ref name="growsup2">{{cite news | author = Jaime J. Weinman | title = South Park grows up | publisher = Macleans.ca| date = 2008-03-12| url = http://www.macleans.ca/culture/entertainment/article.jsp?content=20080312_115131_115131&page=2| accessdate = 2008-04-30}}</ref> as the show's official website describes him as "a normal, average, American, mixed-up kid".<ref>{{cite web|title=Stan Marsh|url=http://www.southparkstudios.com/fans/characters/3|publisher=South Park Studios|accessdate=2009-01-13}}</ref> Kyle is the lone Jew among the group, and his portrayal in this role is often dealt with satirically.<ref name="growsup2"/> Stan and Kyle are best friends, and their relationship, which is intended to reflect the real-life friendship between ''South Park'' creators [[Trey Parker]] and [[Matt Stone]],<ref name="time">{{cite news | author = Jeffrey Ressner and James Collins| title = Gross And Grosser | work = [[Time (magazine)|Time]] | date = 1998-03-23 | url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,988028,00.html | accessdate = 2009-04-28}}</ref> is a common topic throughout the series. Cartmanâloud, obnoxious, and obeseâis sometimes portrayed as an [[antagonist]],<ref name="NPR">{{cite web |url=http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=89375695 |title=Eric Cartman: America's Favorite Little $@#&*% |accessdate=2008-10-25 |last=Rovner |first=Julie |date=2008-04-05 |work=[[National Public Radio|NPR]] }}</ref> and whose [[anti-Semitic]] attitude has resulted in an ever-progressing rivalry with Kyle.<ref name="growsup2"/> Kenny, who comes from a poor family, wears his parka hood so tightly that it covers most of his face and muffles his speech. During the show's first five seasons, Kenny would die in nearly each episode before returning in the next.
Stone and Parker voice most of the male ''South Park'' characters.<ref name="nytimesmorals"/><ref name="growsup2"/><ref name="faq-23apr2002">{{cite web |url = http://www.southparkstudios.com/fans/faq/archives.php?month=4&year=2002 |title = FAQ: April 2002 |accessdate = 2008-10-19 |date = 2002-04-23 |publisher = southparkstudios.com }}</ref> [[Mary Kay Bergman]] voiced the majority of the female characters until her death in 1999, near the end of the [[South Park (season 3)|third season]].<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://www.tv.com/south-park/show/344/cast.html?tag=page_nav;subtabs;cast |title=South Park Cast and Crew on |publisher=Tv.com |date= |accessdate=2010-01-20}}</ref> [[Eliza Schneider]] and [[Mona Marshall]] succeeded Bergman since 1999, and respectively 2000, with Schneider leaving the show in 2003, after the [[South Park (season 7)|seventh season]].<ref name="autogenerated1"/> She was replaced by [[April Stewart]], who, along with Marshall, continues to voice most of the female characters.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> Bergman was originally listed in the credits under the alias Shannen Cassidy to protect her reputation as the voice of several [[Disney]] characters.<ref name="ewbergman">{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,84813,00.html|title=A Voice Silenced |date=1999-11-22|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|accessdate=2009-05-23|last=Bonin|first=Liane}}</ref> Stewart was originally credited under the name Gracie Lazar,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aprilstewart.com/page7.php|title=April Stewart - South Patk|publisher=Aprilstewart.com|accessdate=2009-05-23}}</ref> while Schneider was sometimes credited under her [[rock opera]] performance pseudonym Blue Girl.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.elizaschneider.com/bio.html|title=MY BIO :::: Eliza Jane |publisher=Elizaschneider.com|accessdate=2009-05-23}}</ref> Some ''South Park'' staff members voice other recurring characters; supervising producer [[Jennifer Howell]] voices student [[List of students at South Park Elementary#Bebe Stevens|Bebe Stevens]],<ref name="faq-23apr2002" /> writing consultant [[Vernon Chatman]] voices an [[anthropomorphism|anthropomorphic]] towel named [[List of other South Park residents#Towelie|Towelie]],<ref name="faq-23apr2002" /> and production supervisor [[John 'Nancy' Hansen|John Hansen]] voices [[List of staff at South Park Elementary#Mr. Slave|Mr. Slave]], the former gay lover of [[Herbert Garrison|Mr. Garrison]].<ref name="faq-21nov2003">{{cite web |url = http://www.southparkstudios.com/fans/faq/archives.php?month=11&year=2003 |title = FAQ: November 2003 |accessdate = 2008-10-13 |date = 2003-11-21 |publisher = southparkstudios.com }}</ref> ''South Park'' producer and storyboard artist [[Adrien Beard]], who voices [[List of students at South Park Elementary#Token Black|Token Black]], the only black kid in South Park, was recruited to voice the character "because he was the only black guy [in the] building" when Parker needed to quickly find someone to voice the character during the production of the [[South Park (season 4)|season four]] (2000) episode "[[Cartman's Silly Hate Crime 2000]]".<ref name="faq-30apr2001">{{cite web |url = http://www.southparkstudios.com/fans/faq/archives.php?month=4&year=2001 |title = FAQ: April 2001 |accessdate = 2008-10-19 |date = 2001-04-30 |publisher = southparkstudios.com }}</ref><ref name="hatecrimecomm">{{cite video | people=Trey Parker, Matt Stone|date=2003|title="South Park" - The Complete Fifth Season |medium=DVD|publisher=Comedy Central}} Mini-commentary for episode "Cartman's Silly Hate Crime 2000"</ref> <!--
This list is only for main, supporting, and recurring characters. Only include a character if they have been FEATURED PROMINENTLY IN MULTIPLE EPISODES. One-time and minor characters should not be included.
-->
==Creation and inception== [[Image:Trey Parker Matt Stone 2007.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Matt Stone (right) and Trey Parker (left) created the show and currently voice the majority of the male characters on the show.]]
Creators [[Trey Parker]] and [[Matt Stone]] met during a film class as students at the [[University of Colorado at Boulder|University of Colorado]], and in 1992, they came with an idea for a show that would eventually become ''South Park''. The two discussed filming a three-minute short film involving a boy who befriended a talking stool (feces) named [[List of other South Park residents#Mr. Hankey|Mr. Hankey]].<ref name="HankeyCommentary"/> Instead, Parker and Stone created two Christmas-related animated shorts films called ''[[Jesus vs. Frosty]]'' and ''[[Jesus vs. Santa]]'', which served as precursors to the ''South Park'' series. The low-budget, crudely made ''Jesus vs. Frosty'' film featured [[prototype]]s of the main characters of ''South Park'', including characters resembling [[Eric Cartman|Cartman]], [[Stan Marsh|Stan]], and [[Kyle Broflovski|Kyle]]. [[Fox Broadcasting Company]] executive [[Brian Graden]] saw the film and in 1995 commissioned Parker and Stone to create a second short film that he could send to his friends as a video [[Christmas card]]. Titled ''Jesus vs. Santa'', it resembled the style of the later series more closely.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Littlefield |first=Kinney |title=Comedy Central scores with poop and circumstance;Television: Trey Parker and Matt Stone subvert prime-time comedy with the animated satire "South Park" |work=[[The Orange County Register]]|location=[[Santa Ana, California]] |date=1998-01-28 |page=F04}}</ref>
The video was popular and was widely shared, and when it began to generate interest for a possible television series, Parker and Stone originally conceived the idea of a ''South Park''-like show with four children characters, but with a talking stool named Mr. Hankey as the show's main protagonist; they planned to call it ''The Mr. Hankey Show''. Eventually, Parker and Stone adapted their original idea into a show revolving around the South Park town and four children without Mr. Hankey as a protagonist, but as a minor supporting role in a future episode.<ref name="Commentary">{{cite video | people=Trey Parker, Matt Stone|date=2003|title=South Park: The Complete First Season: "Weight Gain 4000"|format=Audio commentary |medium=CD|publisher=Comedy Central}}</ref> Later, when [[Comedy Central]] expressed interest in the series, and picked up the show. The first episode of the series, "[[Cartman Gets an Anal Probe]]", debuted on Comedy Central on August 13, 1997, as Mr. Hankey would debut in the tenth episode, "[[Mr. Hankey, the Christmas Poo]]".<ref name="HankeyCommentary">{{cite video | people=Trey Parker, Matt Stone|date=2003|title=South Park: The Complete First Season: "Mr. Hankey, the Christmas Poo"|format=Audio commentary |medium=CD|publisher=Comedy Central}}</ref><ref name="DMN0201">{{Cite news |last=Vognar |first=Chris |title=Brats entertainment; "South Park" creators potty hardy on Comedy Central show |work=[[The Dallas Morning News]] |date=1998-02-01 |location=[[Pasadena, California]] |page=1C}}</ref>
In tradition with the show's [[Cutout animation|animation style]], the characters are composed of simple geometrical shapes and uninflected patches of predominantly [[primary color]]s.<ref name="method">{{cite news | author = Matt Cheplic | title = 'As Crappy As Possible': The Method Behind the Madness of South Park | publisher = [[Penton Media]] | date = 1998-05-01 | url = http://digitalcontentproducer.com/mag/video_crappy_possible_method/ | accessdate = 2009-04-28}}</ref><ref name="avr">{{cite news | author = Abbie Bernstein| title = South Park - Volume 2 | publisher = AVRev.com| date = 1998-10-27| url =http://www.avrev.com/dvd-movie-disc-reviews/tv-shows/south-park-volume-2.html| accessdate = 2008-04-30}}</ref> They are not offered the same free range of motion associated with hand-drawn characters, as they are mostly shown from only one angle, and their movements are animated in an intentionally jerky fashion.<ref name="growsup2"/><ref name="method"/><ref name="avr"/> Ever since the show's second episode, "[[Weight Gain 4000]]", all the characters on the show have been animated with computer software, though they are portrayed to give the impression that the show still utilizes the original technique of cutout animation.<ref name="method"/>
==Main characters== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:100%;" |- ! style="width:13%;"| Character ! style="width:22%;"| Voiced by ! class="unsortable" style="width:44%;"| Role ! style="width:21%;"| First appearance
|- | {{sortname|Stan|Marsh}} | [[Trey Parker]]<ref name="faq-23apr2002">{{cite web |url = http://www.southparkstudios.com/fans/faq/archives.php?month=4&year=2002 |title = FAQ: April 2002 |accessdate = 2008-10-13 |date = 2002-04-23 |publisher = southparkstudios.com }}</ref> || One of the original four main boys and one of South Park's more sensible characters. Stan is the [[everyman]] and the leader of the group, often portrayed as the series' main protagonist, trading that role occasionally with Kyle. | ''[[The Spirit of Christmas (short film)|The Spirit of Christmas]]: Jesus vs. Frosty'' |- | {{sortname|Kyle|Broflovski}} | [[Matt Stone]]<ref name="faq-23apr2002" /> || One of the original four main boys and one of few [[Jewish people|Jewish children]] in South Park. Kyle and Stan are the most intelligent members of the group, and Kyle often displays higher moral standards than his friends. He is also often portrayed as the series' main protagonist, especially when it comes to stopping his "friend" Eric Cartman's nefarious schemes. | ''[[The Spirit of Christmas (short film)|The Spirit of Christmas]]: Jesus vs. Frosty'' |- | {{sortname|Eric|Cartman}} | [[Trey Parker]]<ref name="faq-23apr2002" /> || One of the original four main boys, who is an [[obesity|obese]], manipulative, ill-tempered [[racism|racist]] and it was found out that his [[Id, ego and super-ego#Ego|ego]] could change what he thinks happens to him in the episode [[fishsticks]], often portrayed as the series' main [[antagonist]]. Cartman is often brilliant but with misguided motives. | ''[[The Spirit of Christmas (short film)|The Spirit of Christmas]]: Jesus vs. Frosty'' |- | {{sortname|Kenny|McCormick}} | [[Matt Stone]]<ref name="faq-23apr2002" /> || One of the original four main boys and resident of a poor household. Kenny is known for his muffled speech, obsession with sex, and his habit of dying in nearly every early episode of ''South Park''. His frequent deaths and poverty are however somewhat downplayed in later seasons. | ''[[The Spirit of Christmas (short film)|The Spirit of Christmas]]: Jesus vs. Frosty'' |}

He appears as Mintberry Crunch in [[Coon 2: Hindsight]], [[Mysterion Rises]], and [[Coon vs. Coon & Friends]] and gained superpowers | "[[Rainforest Shmainforest]]" |- | [[Leopold "Butters" Stotch ]] | [[Matt Stone]]<ref name="faq-23apr2002" /> || One of the boys' classmates who is very often involved in the antics of the main four. He has received a more prominent role from the fifth season onward (after "[[Kenny Dies]]") and has become somewhat of a sidekick of Cartman, due to his own well-mannered and gullible nature. | "[[Cartman Gets an Anal Probe]]" |- | [[Clyde Donovan]] | [[Trey Parker]]<ref name="faq-30apr2001">{{cite web |url = http://www.southparkstudios.com/fans/faq/archives.php?month=4&year=2001 |title = FAQ: April 2001 |accessdate = 2008-10-13 |date = 2001-04-30 |publisher = southparkstudios.com }}</ref> || One of the boys' classmates and considered himself as the sexiest of the class. | "[[Cartman Gets an Anal Probe]]" |- | [[Craig Tucker]] | [[Matt Stone]]<ref name="premiere1">{{cite web|url=http://celebrity.premiere.com/movie-cast-South+Park |title=South Park - Premiere.com |publisher=Premiere.com |date=1997-08-13 |accessdate=2010-01-20}}</ref> || One of the boys' classmate who occasionally antagonizes them | "[[Cartman Gets an Anal Probe]]" |- | [[Jimmy Valmer]] | [[Trey Parker]]<ref name="faq-23apr2002" /> || One of the boys' two handicapped classmates and an amateur [[standup comedy|standup comedian]] he is known to stutter a lot when he talks due to his disability | "[[Cripple Fight]]" |- | [[Timmy Burch]] | [[Trey Parker]]<ref name="faq-23apr2002" /> || One of the boys' two handicapped classmates whose vocabulary is mostly limited to the enthusiastic shouting of his own name | "[[The Tooth Fairy Tats 2000]]" |- | [[Token Black]] | [[Adrien Beard]]<ref name="faq-30apr2001" /> || The boys' wealthiest classmate and apparently the only black child in the town | "[[Cartman Gets an Anal Probe]]" |- | [[Tweek Tweak]] | [[Matt Stone]]<ref name="faq-18apr2001">{{cite web |url = http://www.southparkstudios.com/fans/faq/archives.php?month=4&year=2001 |title = FAQ: April 2001 |accessdate = 2008-10-13 |date = 2001-04-18 |publisher = southparkstudios.com }}</ref> || The boys' hyperactive and paranoid classmate due to an excessive intake of coffee, although his parents believe it to be because of ADD. | "[[Gnomes (South Park episode)|Gnomes]]" |- | [[Wendy Testaburger]] | [[Mary Kay Bergman]],<ref name="autogenerated1"/> [[Eliza Schneider]],<ref name="autogenerated1"/> [[Mona Marshall]],<ref name="filmreference1">{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/36/Mona-Marshall.html |title=Mona Marshall Biography |publisher=Filmreference.com |date=2002-07-26 |accessdate=2010-01-20}}</ref> [[April Stewart]]<ref name="autogenerated1"/> || One of the boys' classmates, Stan's girlfriend and Bebe's best friend | ''[[The Spirit of Christmas (short film)|The Spirit of Christmas]]: Jesus vs. Santa'' |}

==Former characters== A few characters have had a major role in the past episodes in the show before their death. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:100%;" |- ! style="width:10%;"| Character ! style="width:20%;"| Voiced by ! class="unsortable" style="width:40%;"| Role ! style="width:15%;"| First appearance ! style="width:15%;"| Last appearance |- | [[List of students at South Park Elementary#Pip Pirrup|Pip Pirrup]] | [[Matt Stone]]<ref name="faq-23apr2002" /> || The boys' unpopular English classmate. Gets killed by Mecha-Streisand in "201". | "[[Cartman Gets an Anal Probe]]" | "[[201 (South Park)|201]]" |- | [[Chef (South Park)|Chef]] | [[Isaac Hayes]],<ref name="faq-28jun2001">{{cite web |url = http://www.southparkstudios.com/fans/faq/archives.php?month=6&year=2001 |title = FAQ: June 2001|accessdate = 2008-10-13 |date = 2001-06-28 |publisher = southparkstudios.com }}</ref> [[Peter Serafinowicz]] (Darth Chef)<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/my-secret-life-peter-serafinowicz-actor-and-comedian-age-36-912006.html|title=My Secret Life: Peter Serafinowicz, Actor and comedian, age 36|date=2008-08-30|publisher=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=2009-05-23|last=Philby|first=Charlotte}}</ref> || The school's chef and good friend of the boys, who was killed at the beginning of the [[South Park (season 10)|tenth season]] | "[[Cartman Gets an Anal Probe]]" | "[[The Return of Chef]]" |- | {{sort|Choksondik, Ms.|[[List of staff at South Park Elementary#Ms. Choksondik|Ms. Choksondik]]}} | [[Trey Parker]]<ref name="faq-23apr2002" /> || The boys' former teacher who died during the [[South Park (season 6)|sixth season]] | "[[4th Grade (South Park episode)|4th Grade]]" | "[[The Simpsons Already Did It]]" |- | {{sort|Crabtree, Ms.|[[List of staff at South Park Elementary#Ms. Crabtree|Ms. Crabtree]]}} | [[Mary Kay Bergman]],<ref name="voicechasers1">{{cite web|url=http://voicechasers.com/database/showactor.php?actorid=1109 |title=Mary Kay Bergman - Voice Actor Profile at Voice Chasers |publisher=Voicechasers.com |date= |accessdate=2010-01-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wackyvoices.com/south.html |title=The Babes of South Park |publisher=Wackyvoices.com |date= |accessdate=2010-01-24}}</ref> [[Eliza Schneider]]<ref name="voicechasers2">{{cite web|url=http://voicechasers.com/database/showactor.php?actorid=2827 |title=Eliza Schneider - Voice Actor Profile at Voice Chasers |publisher=Voicechasers.com|date=1978-02-03 |accessdate=2010-01-20}}</ref> || The former school bus driver before her death during the [[South Park (season 8)|eighth season]] | "[[Cartman Gets an Anal Probe]]" | "[[Cartman's Incredible Gift]]" |- | {{sort|Hussein, Saddam|[[Saddam Hussein (South Park)|Saddam Hussein]]}} | [[Matt Stone]]<ref name="faq-23apr2002" /> || A portrayal of [[Saddam Hussein]], who in the show was involved in a homosexual relationship with Satan and built WMD's in heaven | "[[Terrance and Phillip in Not Without My Anus]]" | "[[It's Christmas in Canada]]" |}
==Merchandise== The characters of ''South Park'' have spawned several merchandise items, varying from toys to apparel items. In 2004, the first [[action figure]] collection was released by [[Mirage Toys]] containing five series each with four characters.<ref>http://superherotoys.com/tv---cartoon-toys-south-park.html</ref> In 2006, [[Mezco]] toys released a second collection containing a total of six series, each containing six or four figures.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mezco.net/southpark.html |title=Mezco Toyz | Movie, Television and Proprietary Action Figures & Collectibles |publisher=Mezco.net |date= |accessdate=2010-01-30}}</ref> [[Comedy Central]] itself has made available a variety of products through its website, including t-shirts, figures, hats, pants, and even shot glasses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://shop.comedycentral.com/?v=comedy-central_shows_south-park |title=South Park: DVDs, T-Shirts & Merchandise - Comedy Central Store |publisher=Shop.comedycentral.com |date= |accessdate=2010-01-30}}</ref> A number of fan websites provides an even more extended amount of merchandise, ranging from posters, to magnets, ties and even skateboards,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zazzle.com/southpark/gifts |title=southpark: Products: Zazzle.com Store |publisher=Zazzle.com |date= |accessdate=2010-01-30}}</ref> South Park Studios offer through their website the possibility of creating personalized South Park avatars.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.southparkstudios.com/avatar/ |title=South Park Studios Netherlands |publisher=Southparkstudios.com |date= |accessdate=2010-01-30}}</ref> Similar possibilities have been available on multiple fansites.<ref>{{cite web|author=Midevil917 |url=http://www.newgrounds.com/portal/view/147848 |title=South Park Char Creator 3 |publisher=Newgrounds.com |date= |accessdate=2010-01-30}}</ref>
